trendReport.title: State of AI Coding Tools - February 2026
trendReport.marketOverview: The AI coding tools market in Feb 2026 is maturing from feature-proving to commercialization and enterprise readiness. Broad trends: consolidation of subscription + usage pricing, heavy differentiation through IDE/cloud integration and codebase-awareness, and a bifurcation between fully-managed SaaS assistants and BYOK/self‚Äëhosted/local-model agents. Vendors compete on three vectors ‚Äî integration friction (IDE + CI/CD + cloud), trust/security (BYOK, self-hosting, enterprise SLAs), and cost predictability (flat subscriptions vs usage billing). Free tiers and trials remain important acquisition levers (e.g., Codeium/Windsurf unlimited free completions, many BYOK OSS CLIs), while new paid developer-focused APIs (Claude Code) push usage-based monetization into this category.
keyDevelopments: - Subscription prices compress for individuals (~$9‚Äì$25/mo) while team and enterprise tiers add per‚Äëuser premiums and custom contracts
- BYOK / self‚Äëhosting/local-model options accelerate (Aider, Cline, Continue.dev, Tabnine self-hosted) as security/compliance become purchase drivers
- Usage-based and API-first offerings expand into developer tooling (Claude Code, OpenAI Codex CLI), shifting some cost burden from vendors to heavy-usage teams

- Deep platform integrations win: codebase-aware assistants (Sourcegraph Cody), IDE-embedded experiences (JetBrains AI, Cursor, Zed), and cloud-native tooling (Amazon Q Developer, Replit) differentiate value beyond autocomplete
- Free/unlimited tiers (Codeium/Windsurf) and trials remain effective growth levers, pressuring incumbents to add generous entry tiers or unique capabilities
trendReport.outlook: Over the next period expect intensifying competition on enterprise trust and cost models. Vendors will push stronger enterprise bundles (SLA, on‚Äëprem or VPC deployment, SOC/compliance) and more granular usage controls to attract organizations moving from experimentation to production. BYOK/local-model options and open-source CLIs will continue to gain mindshare among privacy-conscious teams, forcing mainstream players to offer stronger data guarantees and self-hosted variants. Pricing will further bifurcate: predictable subscriptions for everyday developers vs usage/credit models for high-throughput code generation. Finally, expect more vertical specialization (language-, framework-, or codebase-aware assistants) and M&A activity as companies seek to combine deep IDE integration, cloud deployment, and proprietary model access.

comparisons.title: Cursor vs GitHub Copilot vs Windsurf: Complete Comparison
comparisons.introduction: This comparison focuses on three popular IDE-based coding assistants ‚Äî Cursor, GitHub Copilot, and Windsurf (Codeium) ‚Äî because teams and individual developers pick tools based largely on price, limits, and the practical feature differences that affect day-to-day coding (speed, completions, and team/enterprise support). Below I use the supplied pricing and product notes to highlight where each tool stands and which use cases they best fit.
comparisons.pricingComparison:
- Pricing model: All three use subscription pricing.
- Individual (monthly / annual equivalent)
  - Cursor: $20 / mo ‚Üí $240 / year. Free: 2‚Äëweek trial. Note: "500 fast reqs/mo on Pro."
  - GitHub Copilot: $10 / mo ‚Üí $120 / year. No general free tier, but free for students and open‚Äësource maintainers.
  - Windsurf (Codeium): $10 / mo ‚Üí $120 / year. Free tier available; note says "Unlimited completions on free."
- Team (per user / mo ‚Üí per user / year)
  - Cursor: $40 / user / mo ‚Üí $480 / user / year.
  - GitHub Copilot: $19 / user / mo ‚Üí $228 / user / year.
  - Windsurf: $25 / user / mo ‚Üí $300 / user / year.
- Enterprise
  - Cursor: Custom pricing.
  - GitHub Copilot: $39 / user / mo (listed as enterprise price).
  - Windsurf: Custom.
- Value analysis (based on provided facts)
  - Lowest individual recurring cost: Copilot and Windsurf tie at $10/mo; Copilot has additional free access for students/OSS.
  - Best free option for experimentation: Windsurf (true free tier + ‚Äúunlimited completions on free‚Äù).
  - Best team cost: Copilot is cheapest at $19/user/mo. Cursor is the most expensive for teams ($40/user/mo).
  - Premium/performance differentiator: Cursor explicitly notes ‚Äú500 fast reqs/mo on Pro,‚Äù which implies a paid prioritization tier (value for latency-sensitive workflows).
comparisons.featureComparison:
- Free / trial accessibility
  - Windsurf: True free tier, unlimited completions on free ‚Äî strongest for low-friction trial and heavy ad‚Äëhoc use.
  - Cursor: Limited 2‚Äëweek trial only ‚Äî pay to continue beyond trial.
  - Copilot: No general free tier but free for students/OSS contributors ‚Äî strong if you qualify.
- Rate / priority behavior
  - Cursor: Explicitly calls out "500 fast reqs/mo on Pro" (a prioritized/fast request allotment).
  - Windsurf & Copilot: No per‚Äëmonth "fast request" item noted in the provided data.
- Team & Enterprise readiness
  - Copilot: Clear team and enterprise pricing tiers including a listed enterprise price ($39/user/mo) ‚Äî signals a well-established enterprise offering.
  - Windsurf & Cursor: Team and enterprise options available (Cursor team is expensive; both list enterprise as custom except Windsurf where team price is $25 and enterprise is custom).
- Noted strengths from the data
  - Windsurf (Codeium): Unlimited completions on free tier ‚Äî best for experimentation and heavy free usage.
  - GitHub Copilot: Low individual cost, explicit student/OSS free policy, mature GitHub integration implied by name/website (pricing note).
  - Cursor: Offers priority/fast request allocation on paid plan ‚Äî useful where response latency or ‚Äúfast‚Äù completions matter.
- Integrations / other (from supplied data)
  - Each is listed under ‚ÄúIDE-Based Assistants‚Äù and uses subscription pricing. Websites: cursor.com, github.com/features/copilot, codeium.com.
comparisons.verdict:
- If you primarily care about lowest individual cost or you're a student / OSS maintainer: GitHub Copilot or Windsurf (both $10/mo). Copilot is particularly attractive if you qualify for the free student/OSS access.
- If you want a free, no‚Äëcost way to experiment or need lots of completions without hitting limits: Windsurf (Codeium) ‚Äî it explicitly offers a free tier with unlimited completions.
- If you need faster, prioritized responses and are willing to pay more for that experience: Cursor (higher price, with 500 fast reqs/mo on Pro).
- If you are buying for a team and want the lowest per‚Äëuser team price: GitHub Copilot ($19/user/mo) is the best value among the three; Windsurf is mid ($25), Cursor is the most expensive ($40).
- For enterprise buyers: Copilot lists an explicit enterprise price (and strong GitHub/enterprise positioning). Cursor and Windsurf offer custom enterprise plans ‚Äî evaluate on features, SLAs, and privacy/hosting needs.

Short recommendation summary:
- Try Windsurf first if you want free/unlimited experimentation.
- Choose GitHub Copilot for the best price-to-features balance for individuals and cost-effective teams (and if you qualify for student/OSS free access).
- Choose Cursor if you specifically need paid priority/fast requests and are willing to pay a premium for that performance.

comparisons.title: Cline vs Continue vs Roo Code: Complete Comparison
comparisons.introduction: The three tools you asked about sit in the ‚Äúterminal/CLI agents‚Äù space where open‚Äësource, BYOK (bring-your-own-key), and local-model support are common trade-offs vs managed, subscription products. Comparing them matters because your choice affects cost (API usage vs subscription), privacy (local vs cloud), and workflow integration (editor/CLI support). Note: the provided dataset contains entries for Cline and Continue.dev but does not include any data for ‚ÄúRoo Code.‚Äù I‚Äôll compare Cline and Continue using the supplied data and call out the missing Roo Code entry ‚Äî I can add Roo Code if you share its details.
comparisons.pricingComparison:
- Cline (VS Code)
  - From dataset: Open source, free tier = "Open Source", pricing model = BYOK.
  - Practical interpretation: No subscription fees; you pay for whatever model/API keys you supply (OpenAI/Anthropic/etc.). Upfront cost = 0, ongoing cost = your chosen model usage.
- Continue.dev
  - From dataset: Open source, free tier = "Open Source", pricing model = BYOK, notes explicitly state ‚ÄúSupports local models.‚Äù
  - Practical interpretation: Also no subscription fees; you only incur model/API costs if you use hosted models. If you run local models, you may avoid API costs entirely but pay for local compute.
- Roo Code
  - Not in the provided dataset. No pricing data available; cannot compare without more information.

Value analysis (data-driven): both Cline and Continue minimize subscription cost by being open-source/BYOK. That makes them potentially the lowest-cost choices if you already have API access or plan to run local models. Contrast with the dataset‚Äôs Claude Code (usage-based, example "~15‚Äì50/mo") where you pay an external service for model access. If you want predictable per-user pricing or enterprise SLAs, managed subscription products (not Cline/Continue) in the dataset will be more predictable but costlier.
comparisons.featureComparison:
- Category (from dataset): Both are listed under ‚ÄúTerminal/CLI Agents (ü§ñ)‚Äù ‚Äî built for developer workflows that prefer CLI/editor integration and scripting.
- Cline (github.com/clinebot/cline)
  - Key datapoints: Open source, specifically noted as ‚Äú(VS Code)‚Äù in the dataset entry; BYOK.
  - Implication: Tight integration with VS Code editor/extension ecosystem; you bring your own API keys; likely easy to embed into VS Code flows.
- Continue.dev (continue.dev)
  - Key datapoints: Open source, BYOK, explicitly ‚ÄúSupports local models.‚Äù
  - Differentiator: Local model support is explicitly called out; strong option if you need offline capability or on‚Äëprem model hosting for privacy/compliance.
- Direct contrasts (data-driven):
  - Integration: Cline ‚Äî editor/VS Code focus (better if you want an in-editor CLI-style agent). Continue ‚Äî unspecified editor tie-in but notable for local-model support (better if you need offline/on‚Äëprem).
  - Privacy/flexibility: Both are BYOK/open-source (good for privacy). Continue‚Äôs explicit local-model support gives it an edge when you need to avoid cloud APIs entirely.
  - Managed features/support: Neither is a subscription/managed service per dataset; expect more DIY setup and fewer managed SLAs than paid alternatives.
comparisons.verdict:
- If you prioritize in‚Äëeditor experience inside VS Code: pick Cline. According to the dataset, it‚Äôs the VS Code‚Äëfocused open-source BYOK option ‚Äî smallest friction for VS Code users.
- If you prioritize offline/local models or strict on‚Äëprem privacy: pick Continue.dev. The dataset explicitly calls out local-model support, so it‚Äôs the better choice when you want to avoid cloud API usage or run models on local hardware.
- If you want predictable per-user billing, enterprise support, or a fully managed assistant out of the box: neither Cline nor Continue fits that profile (both are BYOK/open-source). Consider managed alternatives in the dataset (e.g., Claude Code for usage-based managed access, or IDE-based paid assistants like GitHub Copilot) depending on budget and SLAs.
- Roo Code: I can‚Äôt recommend for or against it because it‚Äôs not in the provided data. If you paste Roo Code‚Äôs pricing/feature lines (or confirm the correct product name), I‚Äôll update the comparison.

If you want, I can:
- Add a short checklist mapping these tools to specific team scenarios (solo dev, small team, regulated enterprise).
- Incorporate third‚Äëparty API cost examples (OpenAI/Anthropic) to estimate monthly operating costs for each BYOK path.
